int_objec_ht: ['Page 41:\n[¬s]"The contribution of this proposed study to the field of Educational Technology is to try to answer some of the practical questions and to fill some of the gaps that exist in the literature. Using subjects from the third world in general and frcm Libya in particular to investigate the effects of token economy systems and/or immediate knowledge of results on English Language achievement is the main contribution of this study which may provide the literature with facts regarding the generalizability of the theories under investi\xad gation. The second contribution is providing the Libyan Ministry of Education with research based recommendations for practical application to help improve the educational system there. The third contribution and yet with the same value is to provide facts on the differential effects of the variables on the two different sector of the Libyan society e.g. rural versus urban.[¬e]"']

[¬s]"It was assumed that pupils who were required to respond overtly to the lesson content in an unpredictable sequence would feel constrained to attend to the lessons and prepare answers to the lesson questions in anticipation of being asked to respond overtly and would, therefore, achieve highly. It seemed equally reasonable to assume that pupils who could predict when they were to be asked to respond overtly, or who were not required to respond overtly, would not feel constrained to attend to the lessons and prepare answers to the lesson questions to the same extent and would, therefore, have lower achievement.[¬e]"']

['Page 8:\n[¬s]"this evaluation seeks to explore the role and feasibility of Powerful Learning Conversations (PLC). The PLC intervention involves a training programme for Year 9 English and Maths teachers, with the aim of improving feedback practices by applying techniques used in sport. PLC is a feedback intervention which includes focused talk as a fundamental aspect of the learning process. It is based on the idea that feedback techniques used in sport are rapid and immediate and that children are less likely to respond negatively to criticism because of the way in which the feedback is delivered.[¬e]"']
